text: I'm super excited to share with you
today one of the most common ask
questions and that is about kitchen
knives how many knives do you need in
your kitchen you don't need that many to
be quite honest you need about four now
in front of me I have more than four but
I'm going to talk you through which ones
you might need and which ones you might
prefer so starting off an all-purpose
chef's knife which I have here is really
great this is a Western or European
style knife and if you prefer this which
many chefs do then go for this style but
a lot of home cooks and even some chefs
are trading in that chef's knife and
using one of these and this is called a
santoku knife and this is more of an
Asian style knife it typically comes
with these hollow indentations on the
blade of the knife which helps in any
sticky or wet vegetables kind of sliding
off the knife as you chop them so either
of these two knives I prefer them on
different occasions you know depends on
what I'm doing but I would say you only
really need one of these another
important knife to have in the kitchen
is a paring knife I find that this knife
is a great all-purpose knife for peeling
a lot of vegetables coring or hulling
strawberries if you're trimming
artichokes or things like that this is a
really great knife especially for
vegetables very important a serrated
knife now you need a bread knife and
that is a serrated knife I really love
these offset serrated knives because I
think that this is not only good for
bread but it's also good when you're
cutting cakes and pies it just really
helps in getting out a nice slice of
cake or a nice slice of pie and this
offset handle really helps as well
because it allows you a little bit of
room you can see if I bring the knife
down to the cutting board here my
knuckles or my fingers aren't touching
the bottom so that offset handle really
does help and the fourth knife I would
say is a boning knife or some sort of
flexible long blade knife now this is
good for butchering if you're going to
carve a turkey I would say that this is
a very
pourtant knife but it's cousin I would
say this is a carving knife again it is
a flexible blade a thin blade that you
could essentially do some of the same
things with the boning knife and the
carving knife kind of interchangeable
now one other knife that I have or one
of their style of knife that I have is
one of these Japanese knives now
Japanese knives the majority of them
differ from western-style knives like
this in that the blade of the knife is
created in a slightly different way you
can see that the the edge of the knife
the beveled edge here is really only on
one side so I'll flip it over and you
can see that this side doesn't really
have that much of a beveled edge it's
kind of slight on the very very bottom
and this is the way that the knife is
created and also you need to be mindful
of this when you're sharpening a knife
so today I'm going to show you how to
sharpen western-style knives which i
think is most common in everybody's
kitchen so if you're really serious
about your kitchen knives and you want
to keep them as sharp as possible you're
going to need to invest in one of these
now this is called a wet stone or a
sharpening stone and they come one of
two ways so in front of me here I have a
stone that has two levels of grit
coarseness than a fine grit here and
then a coarse grit here so you always
want to start with a coarse side of your
whetstone and then you want to move to
the fine side of your whetstone what you
want to make sure you do before you
sharpen your knives you want to soak the
stone now I'm going to start on the
coarse side which is the smaller number
and you want to soak it in water for
about anywhere between five to ten
minutes what you're really looking for
is any bubbles that appear you want the
bubbles and the air out of the stone you
want it lubricated with as much water as
possible so when the bubbles stop coming
out from inside the stone you know
you're ready to use it so I've been
rotating and soaking for about twenty
minutes in total ten minutes on each
side and I'm going to now start with the
sharpening process now you want to
remove the stone from the water because
you don't want a slippery surface at all
I'm going to use the little cradle that
the stone comes with just so it helps
secure it onto the sir
so the stone isn't moving you might need
a little bit of water and I'll just use
my hands to kind of spread some water on
top of the stone and now you want to
take your knife here and you want to put
it flat against the stone now you're not
going to sharpen flat against the stone
you're going to lift the back end of the
knife up about 15 degrees 15 to 20
degrees and that is about maybe the
thickness of a matchbook I would say and
this is the level at which you're going
to sharpen your knife and what you're
going to do is you're going to take the
knife and you're going to slide it on
that 15 degree angle now you can slide
it towards you or you can slide it away
from you so you want to make sure that
you're starting at one end and going to
the other so one clean motion today I
think I'm going to go away from me so
start at the tip 15 degrees slide on the
stone make sure it's well lubricated and
you're going to come all the way across
the stone and you want to do this maybe
about five six even seven times it
really depends on how dull your knife is
and if you see any chips on the blade of
your knife if you see little divots or
chips you might have to do this a little
bit more especially on the core side
because you're trying to work those out
of the blade of your knife
now I'm going to switch to the other
side you can add a little bit more water
if your stone gets too dry and again
you're going to repeat the same process
where you're dragging the blade on that
15 degree angle from the butt end all
the way to the tip and apply a good
amount of pressure you can see I have my
hand on the knife and I'm holding it
down and this is to ensure that there's
even contact with the stone this looks
pretty good here so that's about five or
six time on each side of the knife and
now I'm going to flip the stone and I'm
going to use the finer side of the stone
to really refine the blade that we're
creating so you're going from a coarse
level now to a finer level so again it's
the same process now you can even hear
the difference in the sound this makes
with a finer stone with a finer grit of
the stone here and there you go you
should have a pretty sharp knife now you
can wipe off a lot of the build-up that
is
accumulated on your knife here and now
for the final step in your knife
sharpening is using one of these and
this is a honing steel this is what this
is called and this is a very fine
texture to it this isn't really
sharpening your knife it's just giving a
very fine edge to it now every time you
use your knife it is a good idea if you
have a honing steel like this to run it
along your honing steel a few times
before you start cooking what you want
to do is you want to make sure that you
have one a honing steel that has this
kind of this but around the end here so
it protects your fingers never grab the
honing steel with your thumb above
otherwise you are likely to cut one of
your fingers so hold it below so you
want to hold the honing blade and the
knife about 45 degrees from the surface
surface of your cutting board or your
counter top and again it's the same
motion where you're going from the butt
end of the knife to the tip and you're
going to run this along your honing
blade applying an even amount of
pressure a few times and I like to do it
from side to side so I'm starting with
one side of the knife and then I'm going
on the opposite end of the honing blade
or the opposite edge of the honing blade
and you can do this maybe five or six
times you really don't need that much
and now give your knife a little bit of
a rinse in water just so any of that
grit
comes off give your blade a good wipe
and you should have an extremely sharp
knife that you can start cooking with
just like a pro now with these tips and
tricks I encourage you shop some new
knives see what's out there find your
favorite and invest in one of these so
you have perfectly sharp knives each and
every time enjoy guys
you
